98% of US-consumed instant formula is made domestically. The supply chain is fragile and prone to supply shocks. The bills I've supported will help to fix this problem by providing an influx of baby formula immediately. (5/5)
I've co-sponsored the Formula Act of 2022 to expand the supply of infant formula by directing the FDA to establish a base international standard for infant formula (HR 7718). (3/5)
I've co-sponsored the Baby Formula Emergency Act which would allow the United States to import infant formula from other countries so long as the product is safe (HR 7822). (4/5)
I have taken three actions to end the infant formula crisis. I voted to provide a waiver to allow those on WIC to buy infant formula that may not be WIC eligible normally (HR 7791). (2/5)

I voted against HR 7790 because despite its title, all it did was provide $28 million to the FDA for staff salaries and expenses. Congress recently allocated $102 million to the FDA with an additional $11 million included for infant health and nutrition. (1/5)

@SusyofAR House Dems rejected a Republican bill to allow existing funds be used to address the crisis while preventing the FDA commissioner from traveling until he submits a plan to address this shortage. I've also co-sponsored a bill to allow the US to expand the supply of infant formula

@SusyofAR I voted against HR 7790 because Congress already provided the FDA an over $100 million increase in funding. This bill throws another $28 million at the FDA and does not require the FDA to come up with a plan to address the shortage.

H.R. 6899 presents a clear choice to Russia and Belarus: end their destabilizing activities in Ukraine or find themselves shut off from emergency liquidity.

Passing this bill sends a clear signal to Beijing that the U.S. won’t tolerate such a move. This bill would also require the Administration to oppose conventional loans to Russia and Belarus if they approach the IMF as a lender of last resort.

Over many months, I urged the Treasury Secretary not to pursue this policy choice...My warnings came long before the invasion of Ukraine even began, yet the Biden Administration didn’t heed these warnings.

More than $17 billion of that was gifted to Putin just last year through the Administration’s approval of a general SDR allocation of $650 billion at the IMF. Nearly a billion dollars in SDRs was given to Belarus as well...
The world is watching, and we must send a message that the United States will not stand idly by and allow SDRs to be used to finance the destruction of Ukraine.
We should be especially concerned by Russia’s ability to exchange its SDRs for Renminbi, especially as Moscow is increasingly forced to turn to China in response to our sanctions.
It would also require the Secretary to work with other IMF member countries to prevent them from doing the same.
